Costello]] | before_party = Fine Gael | after_election = [[Ãamon de Valera]] | after_party = Fianna FÃ¡il }} The '''Irish general election of 1951''' was held on 30 May 1951. The newly elected [[members of the 14th DÃ¡il]] assembled at [[Leinster House]] on 13 June when the new [[Taoiseach]] and [[Government of Ireland|government]] were appointed. The general election took place in [[Parliamentary constituencies in the Republic of Ireland|40 parliamentary constituencies]] throughout [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] for 147 seats in the lower house of parliament, [[DÃ¡il Ãireann]]. ==Campaign== The general election of 1951 was caused by a number of crises within the [[Government of the 13th DÃ¡il|First Inter-Party Government]], most notably the [[Mother and Child Scheme]]. While the whole affair, which saw the resignation of the [[Minister for Health and Children (Ireland)|Minister for Health]], [[NoÃ«l Browne]], was not entirely to blame for the collapse of the government it added to the pressure between the various political parties. There were other problems facing the country such as rising prices, balance of payments problems and two farmer [[Teachta DÃ¡la|TD]]s withdrew their support for the government because of rising milk prices. Although the first inter-party government was now coming to an end it had a number of achievements. It proved that the country could be led by a group other than [[Fianna FÃ¡il]]. It also provided a fresh perspective after sixteen years of unbroken rule by that party. The coalition parties fought the general election on their record on government over the previous three years, while Fianna FÃ¡il argued strongly against coalition governments. ==Result== {{Irish general election header |elec_no = 14th |elec_date = 30 May |elec_year = 1951 |note = {{cite web |url=http://electionsireland.org/results/general/14dail.cfm |title=14th DÃ¡il 1951 General Election |work=ElectionsIreland.org |accessdate=23 May 2009 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.ark.ac.uk/elections/gdala.htm |title=DÃ¡il elections since 1918 |work=ARK Northern Ireland |accessdate=23 May 2009 }} }} {{Irish general election party |party = Fianna FÃ¡il |leader = [[Ãamon de Valera]] |seats = 68 |seats_chg = +1 |seats_% = 46.2 |fpv = |fpv_% = 46.3 |fpv_chg = +4.4 }} {{Irish general election party |party = Fine Gael |leader = [[Richard Mulcahy]] |seats = 40 |seats_chg = +9 |seats_% = 27.2 |fpv = |fpv_% = 25.8 |fpv_chg = +6.0 }} {{Irish general election party |party = Labour Party (Ireland) |leader = [[William Norton]] |seats = 16 |seats_chg = â3The [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] and the [[National Labour Party (Ireland)|National Labour Party]] had reunited since the last election. The figures for the Labour party are compared to the two parties combined totals in the previous election. |seats_% = 10.9 |fpv = |fpv_% = 11.4 |fpv_chg = â2.5 }} {{Irish general election party |party = Clann na Talmhan |leader = [[Joseph Blowick]] |seats = 6 |seats_chg = â1 |seats_% = 4.1 |fpv = |fpv_% = 2.9 |fpv_chg = â2.6 }} {{Irish general election party |party = Clann na Poblachta |leader = [[SeÃ¡n MacBride]] |seats = 2 |seats_chg = â8 |seats_% = 1.4 |fpv = |fpv_% = 4.1 |fpv_chg = â9.2 }} {{Irish general election party |party = Independent (politician) |leader = ''N/A'' |seats = 14 |seats_chg = +2 |seats_% = 9.5 |fpv = |fpv_% = 9.5 |fpv_chg = }} {{Irish general election cc |seats = 1 |seats_chg = ''N/A'' |seats_% = 0.7 }} {{Irish general election total |seats = 147 |seats_chg = 0 |fpv = }} |} *Fianna FÃ¡il minority government formed. The election result was inconclusive. Fianna FÃ¡il's support increased by 61,000 votes, however, the party only gained one extra seat. The coalition parties had mixed fortunes. [[Fine Gael]] were the big winners increasing to forty seats. The [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] patched up its differences with the [[National Labour Party (Ireland)|National Labour Party]] and fought the election together but in spite of this the party lost seats. [[Clann na Poblachta]] were the big losers of the election. Three years earlier the party was a big political threat, but now the party was shattered. Fianna FÃ¡il had not won enough seats to govern alone. However, the party was able to form a government with the support of NoÃ«l Browne, the sacked Minister for Health, and other Independent deputies. ==First time TDs== {{div col}} *[[Philip Brady (Irish politician)|Philip Brady]] *[[Joseph Brennan (Irish politician)|Joseph Brennan]] *[[Patrick Cawley]] *[[Declan Costello]] *[[Patrick Crowe]] *[[Liam Cunningham (Irish politician)|Liam Cunningham]] *[[Percy Dockrell]] *[[Peadar Duignan]] *[[Sir Anthony Esmonde, 15th Baronet|Anthony Esmonde]] *[[John Fanning (politician)|John Fanning]] *[[Michael ffrench-O'Carroll]] *[[SeÃ¡n Flanagan]] *[[Colm Gallagher]] *[[James Hession]] *[[Patrick Hillery]] *[[John Lynch (Kerry politician)|John Lynch]] *[[Peadar Maher]] *[[John Mannion, Snr]] *[[Michael Murphy (Irish politician)|Michael Murphy]] *[[William Murphy (Irish politician)|William Murphy]] *[[Denis J. O'Sullivan]] {{div col end}} ==Re-elected TDs== *[[Laurence Walsh]] ==Outgoing TDs== *[[Sir John Esmonde, 14th Baronet|John Esmonde]] (Retired) *[[John Friel]] (Lost seat) *[[Patrick Gorry]] (Lost seat) *[[James Kilroy (politician)|James Kilroy]] (Lost seat) *[[Michael Lydon]] (Lost seat) *[[Michael Ãg McFadden]] (Lost seat) *[[Joseph Mongan]] (Deceased) *[[Martin O'Sullivan]] (Lost seat) *[[Robert Ryan (Irish politician)|Robert Ryan]] (Lost seat) *[[Richard Walsh]] (Retired) ==See also== * [[Members of the 14th DÃ¡il]] * [[Government of the 14th DÃ¡il]] * [[Parliamentary Secretaries of the 14th DÃ¡il]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Irish elections}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Irish General Election, 1951}} [[Category:Elections in the Republic of Ireland|General election, 1951]] [[Category:1951 in Ireland|General election, 1951]] [[Category:1951 elections in Europe]] [[ca:Eleccions al DÃ¡il Ãireann de 1951]]
